intro: Kadua cookiana var. elatior, commonly known as the Cook Island kōkō, is a flowering plant native to the Cook Islands. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its erect, branched stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in dense, spherical clusters, which are typical of the daisy family. It thrives in coastal and sandy soils, often found in open habitats along the shoreline. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endemic species.
